qg22mj4n.text: Objects illustrated in this volume are from the collection of the University Museum and Art Gallery unless otherwise noted.
Dimensions exclude mounting; height precedes width precedes depth.
Chinese names are given in the traditional order, surnames first.
Scholars who have adopted the Western order place the surname last.
Chinese transliterations for personal names, places, and titles of works follow the Pinyin system of romanisation.
Words adopted into English and commonly used place names, such as Macau, do not follow the Pinyin system.
Foreign terms are italicised unless commonly used in English.

cdr9u9eb.text: The Chinese term 'ci' refers to all ceramics that are fired at high temperatures.
The Chinese term 'ci' includes porcelain and stoneware.
In the West, the term porcelain refers specifically to white ceramics made with a special type of clay called kaolin.
Porcelain is fired to a temperature of about 1300 degrees Celsius.
Firing porcelain results in a translucent, glassy material.
The translucent, glassy material makes a ringing sound when struck.
Stoneware refers to related ceramics that are hard and dense.
Stoneware is made with grey or brown clay.
Stoneware may or may not be white-bodied.
Stoneware is fired to a temperature of 1000 to 1250 degrees Celsius.
Ceramics fired below this temperature range are called earthenwares.
The terms 'protoporcelain' or 'porcellaneous' are sometimes used to describe early ceramics made with some of the same ingredients as porcelain.
The terms 'protoporcelain' or 'porcellaneous' are sometimes used to describe early ceramics with some of the same physical characteristics as porcelain.

hw0eizl9.text: Marks
Other character marks and seal marks may have many different meanings.
Character marks and seal marks may represent a wish for good luck.
Character marks and seal marks may represent a date.
Character marks and seal marks may represent a quality comparison.
Character marks and seal marks may represent an owner or factory.
Character marks and seal marks may represent an indication for use in a specific setting.
Individual potter's marks are rare on Jingdezhen porcelain.
Potter's marks occur much more frequently on porcelain from Dehua.
Marks are usually found on the bottom of a piece.
Marks are sometimes found on the edge or shoulder.
Marks are sometimes found in the centre.
Many different marks can be found on Chinese porcelain.
Imperial marks are the most prevalent in this catalogue.
Imperial marks occur on pieces for the court and related institutions from the Ming dynasty onwards.
They usually consist of six characters in two rows that are read from right to left and from top to bottom.
They sometimes consist of four characters in two rows that are read from right to left and from top to bottom.
They are sometimes written in seal script within a square.
The first two characters indicate the dynasty.
Da Ming means 'the great Ming dynasty'.
The reign name (nian hao) of the ruling emperor is given by the next two.
The reign name could be Jiajing or Wanli.
The last two characters mean 'made during the period of' (nian zhi).
This tradition was continued during the Qing dynasty.
Imperial Ming marks occur on non-imperial wares.
Imperial Qing marks occur on non-imperial wares.
Imperial Ming marks occur on export porcelain.
Imperial Qing marks occur on export porcelain.

hw0eizl9.text: The early modern era was marked by the extension of the Silk Road to Italy.
The early modern era was marked by the beginning of the importation of Eastern goods into Europe in the fourteenth century.
China was the first country in the world to produce high-fired, glazed ceramics.
Porcelain from China was one of the most important elements of this trade.
In the sixteenth century, this trade had expanded to include vast quantities of tea, silk, lacquer, spices, and opium.
This catalogue and its accompanying exhibition tell the story of this trade.
Ceramics from different regions, particularly China and Europe, spread styles, forms, and manufacturing technologies across the globe.
The spread of styles, forms, and manufacturing technologies dramatically altered the course of European and Asian art.
Early Ming dynasty blue-and-white porcelain pieces reached the Ducal court of the Medicis in Florence.
Early export goods reached the Low Countries.
The chronological display begins much earlier than the Ming dynasty.
The chronological display includes a rare Tang dynasty blue-and-white water pot.
The chronological display includes a Yuan dynasty bottle.
The Tang dynasty and Yuan dynasty items predate better-known Ming production.
These ceramics highlight the artistic quality and beauty of Chinese wares.
These ceramics highlight the influence of Chinese wares abroad.
These ceramics highlight the appreciation of Chinese wares abroad.
These ceramics highlight the imitation of Chinese wares abroad.
Ming and Qing dynasty objects were made for local consumption in China.
Ming and Qing dynasty objects were made for export.
Local responses to Ming and Qing dynasty wares existed in Europe.
Local responses to Ming and Qing dynasty wares existed in East Asia.
Local responses to Ming and Qing dynasty wares existed in Southeast Asia.
We move beyond the better-known influences of export to the West.
We include regional varieties of celadon ware in Korea.
We include regional varieties of celadon ware in Thailand.
We would like to thank our exhibition partners, the Asian Civilisations Museum and the Hong Kong Maritime Museum, for their generous loans.
We would like to thank our exhibition partners for their assistance in organising related public programming and publications.
The mission of UMAG exhibitions is to engage with audiences through the discussion of materials and techniques.
The mission of UMAG exhibitions is to engage with audiences through historic exchanges.
The mission of UMAG exhibitions is to engage with audiences through cross-cultural exchanges.
We express our gratitude to Robert Black College for support of the exhibition on their 50th anniversary.
Robert Black College is part of The University of Hong Kong.

y91cel1n.text: Chinese porcelain in Europe and Asia
The first Chinese porcelains arrived in Europe in the fourteenth century.
Small numbers of Chinese porcelains were presented as rare gifts to the ruling houses of Europe via intermediaries in the Middle East.
Delicate, nearly transparent and resistant to extreme heat and moisture, these ceramics were technologically superior to the thick, low-fired European ceramics made before the eighteenth century.
These ceramics were regarded as objects of great rarity and luxury.
Their construction was so poorly understood that European collectors often had them mounted in gilt silver or gold.
European collectors mounted them in a manner similar to naturalia (‘natural wonders’) like ostrich eggs and large shells.
The mounting emphasised their preciousness and transformed them into entirely different objects.
Extraordinary objects were often displayed in cabinets of curiosities.
Cabinets of curiosities were collections that attempted to categorise and tell stories about the wonders of the natural world.
By the early sixteenth century, Portugal established trade routes to the Far East and began commercial trade with Asia via Portuguese-controlled ports in Macau, Malacca, and Dejima.
Porcelain became an important component of the wider trade in silk, spices, tea, ivory, metalwork, and lacquer between East and West.
Major production centres like Jingdezhen in Jiangxi province responded to demand in Europe by producing large amounts of porcelain specifically for export.
The porcelain produced for export was transported and used as a form of ballast in large merchant ships.
New arrivals like the Dutch and British built
The word porcelain originated with the Venetian traveller Marco Polo.
Marco Polo saw white-bodied ceramics being made in China for the court of Kublai Khan.
He called them porcelanna, Italian for a white seashell.
Porcelanna soon became the standard term in Europe.
China had been producing porcelain of the highest quality for markets across the globe long before the arrival of Europeans.
From the sixth to twentieth centuries, Chinese kilns produced magnificent display pieces for the imperial court.
From the sixth to twentieth centuries, Chinese kilns produced vast quantities of bowls, plates, and dishes intended for everyday use.
From the sixth to twentieth centuries, Chinese kilns produced bowls, plates, and dishes for export to Southeast Asia, Japan, Korea, and the Islamic world.
The appeal of these works lay in their technical achievement.
The appeal of these works lay in their association with Chinese art and culture.
Chinese art and culture have long been viewed as a source of learning, tradition, and vast wealth.

The fashion for collecting these objects spread so quickly as to appear almost contagious.
The fashion for collecting these objects was described by some enthusiasts as la maladie die porcelaine—‘porcelain-sickness’.

Daniel Marot is often linked to the late Baroque style.
His designs for several rooms of Kensington Palace demonstrate the typical high-density approach to porcelain display of the late Baroque period.
The appearance of these objects changed in step with tastes in Europe.
Consumers at times favored designs that depicted an exotic East.
Western patterns with prominent armorial crests or landscapes and figures taken from prints were preferred at other times.
European designs were transmitted via a well-established trading network.
The trading network carried models to China.
The models were copied onto special services.
A Dutch charger had the arms of Amsterdam inscribed 'AMSTEL DAM.'
A porcelain ewer had the seal of Portugal painted upside down.
Europeans affected artistic change by bringing new technologies and techniques to China.
Europeans introduced the famille-rose palette to China, which means 'rose family' in French.
The famille-rose palette was employed widely on both domestic and export porcelain.
Guiseppe Castiglione was a Jesuit painter patronised by the Kangxi, Yongzheng and Qianlong emperors.
Guiseppe Castiglione famously introduced Western painting techniques such as single-point perspective to Chinese artists.
Western painting techniques found expression across a variety of mediums.
Chinese ceramics inspired competition in Asia at first.
Chinese ceramics later inspired competition in Europe.

The Dutch exposed the Arita potters to Chinese underglaze blue porcelain, which was popular in Europe.
The Arita potters could use Chinese underglaze blue porcelain as an example in their own work.

qzxf4whz.text: Porcelain manufactories in Europe
Portuguese traders successfully returned home with samples of kaolin, which they discovered in China to be essential in the production of porcelain wares.
Europeans remained ignorant of the techniques and processes involved in the production of porcelain until 1708.
The first European hard-paste porcelain was made in Meissen, Germany in 1708 by Johann Friedrich Böttger.
European hard-paste porcelain is made from a compound of the feldspathic rock petuntse and kaolin clay fired at around 1400 degrees Celsius.
With support from the porcelain-obsessed

1370– 1570) by scholars like Roxanna Brown, these interruptions occurred between 1325 and 1380.
The second severe shortage of blue-and-white porcelain caused China's market share of ceramic production to decrease to 50%.
China's market share of ceramic production decreased from 1368 to 1424–1430.
The percentage decreased to 5% from 1424–1430 to 1487.
The percentage rebounded during the reign of the Hongzhi emperor.
The percentage declined once again until the formal rescinding of the haijin ('sea ban') in 1567.

They lacked access to naturally occurring kaolin clay, a mineral rich in silicates that gives porcelain much of its strength.
They emulated the beauty of pure white porcelain using white slip, a liquefied suspension of clay particles in water.
White slip was often embellished with painted decoration in blue pigments derived from cobalt oxide.
Vietnamese potters developed their own unique ceramics following the introduction of Chinese examples towards the end of the Tran dynasty.
Vietnamese ceramics were more heavily potted than Chinese wares.
Vietnamese ceramics were slightly off-white in color.
These wares were produced at major kiln sites like Chu Dou and Bát Tràng near Hanoi.
These wares benefited from the first of several interruptions to porcelain production in China, brought about by social unrest and dynastic change.
By the fifteenth century, these wares formed part of a lively intra-Asian trade in ceramics with Malaysia, Thailand, Indonesia, and the Philippines.
Nearly five centuries of Goryeo dynasty rule in Korea lasted from 918 to 1392.
During the Goryeo dynasty, blue-green celadons inspired by wares from China became the dominant type of ceramics produced on the Korean peninsula.
Korean potters arrived in Japan during two invasions of Korea led by Toyotomi Hideyoshi in the 1590s.
Korean potters took an active role in the development of porcelain production in Japan.
The early porcelain wares produced in Arita were called Imari, named after a port near the kilns.
The early porcelain wares had a coarse, grainy texture.
The early porcelain wares featured fluid, free-form designs in various shades of blue.
They were influenced by Korean monochrome porcelain.
They were influenced by Chinese monochrome porcelain.
They were influenced by less formal blue-and-white wares from southern Chinese kilns.
The export wares from southern Chinese kilns were made to conform to the aesthetic of the Japanese tea ceremony.
Later Imari wares were consciously designed to cater to Western tastes.
Later Imari wares became much more colourful and regimented.
Later Imari wares at times achieved more access in Europe than their Chinese counterparts.

qzxf4whz.text: Augustus II the Strong of Saxony owned 35,798 pieces of porcelain at the time of his death in 1733.
This was the largest collection of porcelain in Europe at the time.
Böttger established a factory at Meissen, just outside Dresden, in 1710.
The factory was soon producing large amounts of hard-paste porcelain.
In the 1720s, the Meissen factory developed a new and extensive range of enamel colours.
The factory’s painters excelled in fantastic depictions of life in an imagined Far East.
Claudius du Paquier founded a second factory in Vienna after earlier successes.
The former kiln master from Meissen assisted in the founding of the second factory in Vienna.
The factory in Vienna began making hard-paste porcelain by about 1719.
A number of factories opened in Germany in the 1740s and 1750s.
Workers from Meissen or Vienna often provided the necessary technical expertise for these factories.
The discoveries in Meissen were followed by the establishment of major factories elsewhere in Europe.
Soft-paste porcelain, an imitation low-fired porcelain, lacked the ingredients found in hard-paste porcelain.
Soft-paste porcelain had been made at the Medici workshops in Italy since the late sixteenth century.
Francesco Vezzi established a porcelain factory in Venice in 1720.
The factory began producing hard-paste porcelain in significant numbers in 1720.
Experiments by the Marchese Carlo Ginori led to the development of a hard-paste porcelain factory in Doccia near Florence in 1737.
The factory produced works inspired by delicate white wares from Dehua.
Both men were assisted by workers from the Du Paquier factory.
Doccia porcelain from the 1740s sometimes features painted decoration that reflects the influence of Du Paquier porcelain.
The atmosphere of technological and stylistic exchange characterised the European ceramic industry of the eighteenth century.
of the eighteenth century.
Innovative and experimental new forms were always in development.
The factory looked to different sources of inspiration, such as Japanese lacquer.
By the mid-1750s, the factory had overtaken the Meissen factory in terms of production.
By the mid-1750s, the factory had overtaken the Meissen factory in terms of innovation.
It remained at the forefront of European porcelain production for the rest of the century.
English manufacturers struggled to discover the secrets of making porcelain without access to the necessary ingredients.
Between the 1740s and 1760s, English manufacturers were only able to develop formulae that created a range of soft-paste porcelains unsuitable for tableware.
The discovery of kaolin clay in Cornwall in 1746 was made by an English chemist named William Cookworthy.
William Cookworthy soon found better-quality clay in St Stephen's, near St Austell.
Cookworthy patented his recipe for making porcelain after two decades of experimentation.
Cookworthy established the Plymouth China factory in 1768.
The Plymouth China factory was the first in England to manufacture hard-paste porcelain.
By the turn of the century, England had a flourishing porcelain industry.
England had porcelain factories in Derby, Worcester, Staffordshire, Liverpool, and elsewhere.
These ventures were primarily commercial and operated without noble or royal financial support.
These ventures were run by entrepreneurs and artisans.
Much of the output of these ventures was aimed at a growing middle class.
The European factories were so successful that the demand for Chinese porcelain began to diminish.
Towards the end of the eighteenth century, the trade in Chinese porcelain fell into serious decline.
Centuries of genuine artistic exchange stimulated by the trade in porcelain left an indelible mark on the arts of Europe.
Chinese ceramics remain a potent source of design ideas for artists today.
Artists today work in fields as diverse as architecture, interior design, theatre, and painting.

Ben Chiesa   
Assistant Curator, University Museum and Art Gallery,   
The University of Hong Kong
Kaolin was not discovered in France until the second half of the eighteenth century.
All French porcelain produced before 1770 was soft-paste rather than hard-paste.
Both types were first made in factories which had previously produced faience, a type of tin-glazed earthenware.
Factories in Rouen and Saint-Cloud had previously produced faience.
The Sèvres factory was in the western part of Paris.
The Sèvres factory moved from its former premises in Vincennes in 1756.

With the financial backing of King Louis XV (r. 1715–1774), the Sèvres factory soon came to dominate not only the French ceramic industry, but also the entirety of European ceramics for the second half

eborpipm.text: Blue-and-white
Blue-and-white porcelain may have been the first truly global commodity.
Blue-and-white porcelain reached a wider audience than any other type of Chinese ceramic.
Ceramics were sent to markets in Southeast Asia, Japan, Korea, India, the Middle East, and Africa.
These ceramics inspired potters in major ceramic centres to produce elegant ceramics of their own design.
Fifteenth-century Iznik potters produced rich turquoise fritwares.
Seventeenth-century Arita potters produced elaborately panelled Japanese kraak wares.
Blue-and-white porcelain was the first type of porcelain to be collected in Europe in large numbers.
Blue-and-white porcelain sparked a craze for things Chinese in the sixteenth century.
The craze for things Chinese lasted well into the nineteenth century.
New generations of artists and collectors rediscovered and renewed the art form of blue-and-white porcelain.
The earliest surviving Chinese blue-and-white ceramics were made in the Tang period.
Kilns in northern China dominated the production of high-fired white stonewares during the Tang period.
Kilns in northern China dominated the production of porcelains during the Tang period.
This was a shared creation of China and the Islamic Middle East.
They were decorated with cobalt blue imported from northeast Persia or the Arabian Peninsula.
Decorative techniques invented by potters in Basra, Iraq were used to embellish tin-glazed earthenwares.
These earthenwares were developed in imitation of Chinese white wares.
The development of these earthenwares demonstrates the remarkable hybridity of early ceramic industries in Asia.
Tang blue-and-white ceramics represented a brief period of experimentation.
This experimentation was not repeated until the fourteenth century.
Strong familial, cultural, and economic ties to the Islamic world contributed to the resurgence of blue-and-white ceramics in the fourteenth century.
The stabilisation of overland trade routes under the Mongol-led Yuan dynasty opened new markets.
The stabilisation of trade routes made access to imported cobalt easier.
Yuan imperial patronage turned the kilns of Jingdezhen in Jiangxi province into the largest porcelain production centre in China.
A cultural policy promoted artistic exchange between different ethnic groups.
This patronage created an atmosphere of experimentation.
The atmosphere of experimentation allowed new forms and styles to develop.
Highly finished works were intended for the court.
Less formal wares were intended for the export market.
Less formal wares were transported along the silk road.
Less formal wares were transported from major ports like Canton and Quanzhou.
The success of Yuan blue-and-whites laid the foundations for the dominance of the export industry in the Ming and Qing dynasties.
Millions of ceramics were produced in the imperial kilns during the Ming and Qing dynasties.
Millions of ceramics were produced in private commercial enterprises during the Ming and Qing dynasties.
Specific designs were tailored for certain markets.
These designs often found their way to other places.
The Portuguese purchased blue-and-white porcelain made for the Malay Peninsula in Malacca.
When the Dutch established a foothold in the Indonesian Archipelago in the first decades of the seventeenth century, they gained access to the important transshipment hub of Batavia (Jakarta).
Over twelve million Chinese ceramics were shipped to Holland from Batavia between 1607 and 1684.
Not all of these porcelains were designed with European consumers in mind.
Dutch still-life oil paintings reveal that porcelains in shapes seemingly made for non-European customers were sold in Europe.
Dutch still-life oil paintings reveal that porcelains in shapes seemingly made for non-European customers were used in Europe.
Blue-and-white porcelain remained the most popular export form until the end of the seventeenth century.
Growing European interest in wares decorated with coats of arms encouraged the use of polychrome enamels.
Polychrome enamels allowed for more detailed and accurate depictions of heraldry.
The Jingdezhen kilns are still the most important kilns in China.
The Jingdezhen kilns responded to the demand for colourful porcelain.
The trade in colourful porcelain supplanted blue-and-white porcelain in the eighteenth century.
The trade in colourful porcelain became the defining aspect of Chinese export porcelain in the eighteenth century.

Gongyi, China (Tang dynasty), probably 9th century   
Stoneware, height 7.5 cm   
HKU.C.1953.0028
This water pot is a rare example of early blue-and-white pottery from the Tang dynasty.
The water pot is sparsely decorated with horizontal blue dashes and dots over a crackled transparent glaze.
The decoration on the water pot is reminiscent of the freeform brown and green designs on Changsha wares from Hunan.
The shape of the pot resembles Tang period tripod vessels.
Tang period tripod vessels were used by scholars to clean brushes and add water to ink.
Chinese blue-and-white ceramics from the Tang period were virtually unknown until 1975.
Shards recovered from the coastal city of Yangzhou in Jiangsu province in 1975 confirmed the existence of Tang period blue-and-white ceramics.
Most of the early blue-and-white wares were likely made at kilns in Gongxian, now Gongyi county, in Henan province.
A number of dishes were recovered in 1998 from the wreck of a ninth-century Arab dhow which sank near Belitung Island in Indonesia.
The oldest Arab ship discovered in Asian waters carried 60,000 pieces of Chinese ceramics.
The ceramics were loaded at Yangzhou and intended for markets in Southeast Asia and the Middle East.

pzj2l5p0.text: Bottle (yuhuchun)
China (Yuan dynasty), 14th century Porcelain with underglaze blue, height 25.5 cm HKU.C.1978.0632
Bottles of this shape take their name from Song dynasty literary references to decanters for rice wine called yuhuchun.
Bottles of this shape may also have been used as water containers.
Chinese porcelains were highly prized by the upper echelons of Chinese society.
Chinese porcelains were popular exports to Southeast Asia, Korea, Japan, India, and the Middle East.
Chinese porcelains have been recovered from excavations as far afield as Kenya.
They were made in a variety of forms to suit different tastes.
The forms included monochrome examples, blue-and-white examples, and overglaze painted examples.
Some forms included elaborately gilded works in precious silver.
The earliest surviving porcelain yuhuchun are monochrome wares.
The earliest surviving porcelain yuhuchun date to the Song dynasty.
These early yuhuchun seem to have been particularly well received in Japan.
These early yuhuchun were favoured by tea masters in Japan.
The first Chinese porcelains arrived in the West in the fourteenth and fifteenth centuries.
They were presented as rare gifts to the ruling houses of Europe.
The porcelains were sent via intermediaries in the Middle East.
Yuhuchun decorated with cobalt blue were not produced until the Yuan dynasty.
The reopening of overland trade routes between China and Central Asia during the Yuan dynasty allowed Chinese potters to import high-quality cobalt more easily.
Blue-and-white yuhuchun were made on a larger scale than earlier examples.
Blue-and-white yuhuchun were sometimes made in faceted shapes.
Making blue-and-white yuhuchun in faceted shapes reflected different approaches in the Yuan dynasty to the properties of clay as an expressive medium.
Song yuhuchun were mostly thrown on the potter's wheel and allowed to grow naturally into shapes with minimal guidance from the potter's hands.
Yuan examples make greater use of the plastic quality of the clay in modelling and moulding.
They were often decorated with imagery inspired by designs found on objects from the Islamic world.
The patterns resembling Islamic calligraphy on this bottle are inspired by designs from the Islamic world.
A bronze bottle with incised chrysanthemum sprays was recovered from the Sinan shipwreck of 1323.
The panelled designs on this example are replaced with chrysanthemum sprays on the bronze bottle.
For the latter, see a Song yuhuchun in the Far Eastern Ceramics Museum, Japan, illustrated in Hobson et al.
A yuhuchun named the Fonthill Vase was named for its previous owner William Beckford of Fonthill Abbey.
William Beckford acquired the Fonthill Vase on one of his trips to Paris in 1793, 1803, or 1814.
The Fonthill Vase is one of the earliest recorded Chinese porcelain vessels to have been exported to Europe.

The surface flaws were described positively as mushikui, ‘worm-eaten’ in Japanese.
These wares were termed ko-sometsuke (‘old blue-and-white’) by nineteenth-century Japanese connoisseurs.

The transitional period in Chinese ceramic production is generally assumed to have started with the death of the Ming Wanli emperor in 1620.

Chinese art uses homophones to create visual puns.

1600–1050 BCE) and Zhou (ca.
1046–256 BCE) dynasties.
The round mid-section is distinct from the more angular mid-sections of the ancient gu.
The round mid-section is a feature of late Shunzhi and early Kangxi vases.
The basic forms of antiquarian objects like gu had been absorbed into the repertory of the Jingdezhen potters by the Kangxi period.
The forms of antiquarian objects were used widely for a variety of purposes.
The pairing of the shape with literati subject matter on this vase suggests that it was chosen deliberately to appeal to the scholarly class.

Customers in the West were fascinated by the landscapes they saw in Chinese paintings and ceramics.
Customers in the West wanted European porcelain decorated with similar designs.

Asian motifs were combined with Western embellishments in this design.

glb70wof.text: Bowl with brown glaze
Large quantities of bowls and dishes with underglaze blue decoration on the interior and deep brown glazes on the exterior were produced in Jingdezhen during the early eighteenth century.
The fashion for Chinese porcelain was at its highest in Europe during the early eighteenth century.
High concentrations of iron oxide were added to the glaze during the firing process to make porcelain wares of this type.
Iron oxide was usually added in the form of iron filings.
Porcelain wares of this type were referred to as 'Batavian ware'.
Batavian ware was named after the major Dutch port in Indonesia through which the wares were shipped.
François Xavier d’Entrecolles, a French Jesuit priest, described porcelains of this type as tse-kin (‘golden brown’) in letters sent to his superiors in 1712 and 1722.
He observed that they were one of the main wares manufactured for the Qing court on a regular basis.
He observed that this was a recent invention.
The long history of brown glazes in China suggests that he was referring specifically to technical processes used in the early eighteenth century.
He was not referring to brown-glazed porcelain in general.
These wares were particularly popular in the Netherlands.
Significant quantities of these wares were recovered from the foundered Swedish East Indiaman Gotheborg, which sank in 1745.
These wares were exported to Northern Europe in large quantities.
Items were shipped to America after America entered the China trade in 1784.
The decoration was revived in the early nineteenth century.
The decoration was primarily used on wares intended for export to Southeast Asia.
This bowl was recovered from the Nanking cargo.
The Nanking cargo is the wreck of a Dutch East India Company ship.
The ship left Canton in December 1751 with more than 230,000 pieces of porcelain, textiles, and tea for the European market.

The bowl is delicately decorated with a landscape scene showing willows, blossoming peonies, and pavilions.
The most striking feature of the chrysanthemum-shaped bowl is the epitaph incised in black ink on the exterior.
A reign mark attributes the production of the item to the forty-first year of the Qianlong emperor’s reign.
A carved inscription on the foot identifies its subject as cong wuyi Ruren, the wife of an imperial official.
The text provides her name, Zou, and nickname, Jugu, 'lady of chrysanthemum'.
The dish presumably takes its shape from the nickname, 'lady of chrysanthemum'.
A detailed account of her family background follows.
Ruren was the title granted for the mothers of imperial officials of the seventh rank and higher during the Ming and Qing dynasties.
Ruren was the title granted for the wives of imperial officials of the seventh rank and higher during the Ming and Qing dynasties.
Traditional epitaphs were often carved on stones.
Traditional epitaphs were often carved on ceramics.
They described the experiences, merits, and accomplishments of the deceased.
They were mostly reserved for imperial officials and their family members.
The eulogy on this bowl associates Zou with many of the feminine virtues in dynastic China.
The feminine virtues in dynastic China include the Confucian triad of obedience as a daughter, wife, and mother.
Both 'willow' and 'stay' are pronounced liu in Chinese.
The presence of the willow at the center of the bowl was likely an expression of yearning for Zou from her family.
The porcelains in this section are extremely fine and evenly toned.
The porcelains in this section were made in the kilns of Dehua in Fujian province, southern China.
Fujian is a tea-growing region that attracted the attention of European merchants in the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries.
Many of the objects from Fujian were brought back to Europe.
In Europe, this type of white Dehua porcelain became known as blanc de Chine, which is French for 'white of China'.
The items were exported to Japan in large quantities.
Dehua specialised in whitewares.
The most highly prized whitewares were those with an ivory-coloured glaze.
Seventeenth-century literary sources note that the translucent appearance of Dehua whitewares was the result of 'truly fine' porcelain stone.
The porcelain stone was dug by driving a shaft into the side of a nearby hill.
The material was then pulled out with a rope.
The earliest pieces of Dehua porcelain were made of locally mined porcelain stone.
The earliest pieces of Dehua porcelain contained little or no clay.
The earliest pieces of Dehua porcelain were thinly potted.
The Dehua kilns had no access to water transportation.
Until the arrival of foreign merchants, most of the products from the Dehua kilns were sold locally.
The most common types of Dehua products were incense burners.
The most common types of Dehua products were Buddhist figures moulded and finished by hand.
In China, these were usually placed on household altars.
The latter were worshipped as devotional images.
Exotic curiosity items were brought to Europe during the seventeenth century.
These items were placed on tables and cabinets in the residences of aristocrats and wealthy people.
Exotic curiosity items were exhibited in 'porcelain rooms'.
By the eighteenth century, Europeans were familiar with Chinese polychrome ceramics.
Dehua wares may have been seen as too plain by comparison.
Many Dehua wares were gilded or enamelled in Europe to make them more attractive to customers.
The Dehua kilns produced objects tailored for the European market.
The Dehua kilns produced figures of Dutch men and women for the European market.
The Dehua kilns produced Christian figures for the European market.
These wares were closely copied at European porcelain factories.
European porcelain factories include Meissen, Chantilly, and Bow.

twrx1ni3.text: Guanyin figure
This figure was likely made for domestic use and worshipped on a small household altar.
This figure represents the Chinese Guanyin, a bodhisattva ('enlightened being'), sitting on a rock in the 'royal ease' position.
Her body is dressed in loosely fitting robes that fall open at the chest.
The loosely fitting robes reveal a lotus-shaped pendant.
The loosely fitting robes leave only her right foot uncovered.
The head is slightly lowered and bears a jewelled crown.
The jewelled crown is placed on neatly arranged hair in a high chignon.
The hair and chignon are covered by a cowl.
The exterior is fully covered by a white glaze with a slightly blueish hue.
The base rim and the interior are left uncovered.
The object is moulded in different sections.
Guanyin is the bodhisattva of compassion.
Guanyin is one of the most popular Buddhist figures in China.
She originated in India as the male bodhisattva Avalokitesvara.
Avalokitesvara was transformed after the introduction of Buddhism into China into a female bodhisattva associated with the virtues of compassion and mercy.
The transformation process of Avalokitesvara is not well understood.
Guanyin was worshipped as the patron of fishermen.
Guanyin was worshipped by women as a fertility goddess.
Guanyin was worshipped as the 'bringer of sons.'
Early images of a cowled female bodhisattva dating from the Song dynasty have been found at the ancient Buddhist cave shrines of Maijishan in cave 165, Gansu province.
Early images of a cowled female bodhisattva dating from the Song dynasty have been found at the ancient Buddhist cave shrines of Dazu in cave 136, Chongqing.
From the seventeenth century onwards, the porcelain kilns at Dehua were celebrated for their production of Buddhist models.
Guanyin figures were prominent among the Buddhist models produced at Dehua.
The figural subjects appear to have been the most popular during the reign of the Wanli emperor.
The figural subjects appear to have been the most popular through to the end of the Qing dynasty.
Dehua, China (Qing dynasty), Kangxi period, 1662–1722 Porcelain with ivory glaze, height 23.5 cm HKU.C.1953.0014

myfaj4o2.text: This Virgin and Child sculpture was made for Christians in Asia and the West.

When depicted with a child, Guanyin was known as the 'bringer of sons'.

The figures can be clearly identified based on the curly hair of the child.
The figures can be clearly identified based on the non-Chinese headdress of the woman.
The figures can be clearly identified based on the orb with a cross in the hands of the infant.
The orb with a cross in the hands of the infant is known as the globus cruciger in Latin and is part of Christian iconography.

Dated inventories show that figures of a woman and child, probably representing Guanyin, were in the Dresden porcelain collection of Augustus II the Strong, King of Poland and Elector of Saxony (1670–1733).

Figures of a woman and child, probably representing Guanyin, were also in the smaller collection of William III, King of England (r. 1689–1702) and Queen Mary II (r. 1689–1694) at Kensington House, London.

The kilns at Dehua produced figurines and serving vessels.

The Malay term kendi derives from the Sanskrit word for ritual pouring vessels used in India called kundika.
The ritual pouring vessels called kundika were originally made of bronze and other metals.
They typically have a bulbous body.
They have a neck which is used for holding the vessel.
They have a spout.
This example is incised with a scrolling floral pattern.
The scrolling floral pattern was popular from the Tang dynasty onwards.
Ceramics were used in Southeast Asia from at least as early as the ninth century.
Ceramics found less utility in China.
Ceramics were instead made in porcelain from about the fourteenth century for markets in Malaysia, Indonesia, Thailand, Vietnam, and the Philippines.
Porcelain ceramics were shipped from the ports of Quanzhou and Fuzhou.
By the sixteenth century, Chinese ceramics were carried farther afield to the Middle East.
Persian copies of Chinese ceramics were made in the Middle East.
Persian copies of Chinese ceramics were sometimes adapted for use as waterpipes for smoking tobacco.
The items were brought to Europe via Portuguese and Dutch traders in the seventeenth century.

wbifmijh.text: Enamelled porcelain
The decoration of ceramics with colourful patterns in China started with sancai or 'three-colour' wares from the Tang period.
During the late Ming and Qing dynasties, the trade in porcelain between China and the West reached new heights.
Porcelains decorated in red, green, and yellow with outlines of blackish cobalt or underglaze blue called wucai (‘five-colour’) became the most widely produced polychrome wares.
Depending on the prominence of certain colours, Chinese ceramics came to be known in Europe by names such as famille verte ('green family') and famille rose ('rose family').
The terms famille verte and famille rose were used by the French Jesuit and ceramic collector Albert Jacquemart in 1873.
Colours were added to porcelain by applying enamels, which are powdered glass mixed with pigments, to unglazed clay that had been through one firing.
Colours were added to glazed ceramics, sometimes with underglaze decoration in blue applied beforehand.
The enamels were fused to the surface through a second firing at a relatively low temperature of about 900°C.
Major advancements in the production of polychrome porcelain were achieved in the early eighteenth century.
The Kangxi emperor, a patron of the arts, supported experimentation at the imperial kilns in Jingdezhen.
European Jesuits at court brought knowledge of Western chemistry.
These innovations included the use of a greater percentage of kaolin in the firing process.
These innovations included the subtle use of shading in new colours like pink and white.
Changes to the composition and firing of glazes led to the invention of complex hues like 'peachbloom' and 'oxblood red'.
Enamelled porcelain proved hugely successful in Europe.
Large amounts of enamelled porcelain were purchased by the Dutch East India Company in the seventeenth century.
Large amounts of enamelled porcelain were purchased by the British East India Company in the seventeenth century.
The trade was briefly interrupted when the Qing dynasty cut off porcelain exports from 1644 to 1684.
Traders turned to the Arita kilns in Japan during this period.
The brightly coloured objects purchased from there were popular enough to influence trends.
Chinese makers were forced to imitate Japanese styles when Chinese exports resumed.
European manufactories later produced their own synthesised versions, incorporating stylistic features
found on export ceramics from both countries.
Facing strong competition from China and Japan, they developed a wide range of goods aimed at different classes.
They developed fine ornamental pieces for the fashion-conscious.
They developed simply decorated items for daily use.
Enamelled porcelain tended to be more expensive than blue-and-white porcelain.
Blue-and-white porcelain could be produced in a single firing.
Enamelled porcelain also tended to be more expensive.
It was seen as particularly suitable for special commissions with personalised decoration, such as coats of arms.
It could replicate designs better than blue-and-white porcelain.
An interest in armorial porcelains drove much of the demand for enamelled porcelains in Europe in the eighteenth century.
An interest in armorial porcelains drove much of the demand for enamelled porcelains in Europe in the nineteenth century.
Many types of enamelled porcelain were produced for export to parts of Asia in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries.
Colourful and boldly patterned ceramics like Zhangzhou ware had been traded in parts of Asia since the late Ming dynasty.
Some ceramics were decorated with unique palettes and motifs not found on ceramics for other markets.
The vividly contrasting colours and Hindu-Buddhist iconography of 'Bencharong' were made for the Siamese court.
The auspicious symbolism and bright pinks, greens, and yellows of 'nyonya ware' were made for Peranakan Chinese communities in the Straits Settlements.

These ceramics are decorated in the wucai ('five-colour') palette.
The outlines of these ceramics are in underglaze blue.

The production of wucai porcelain was first developed during the reign of the Jiajing emperor.
The production of wucai porcelain flourished in the Wanli period.
These emperors commissioned a variety of porcelain objects decorated in this style.
The porcelain objects were made in both the imperial kilns and private commercial enterprises.
These plates are decorated on the interior with an imperial five-clawed dragon.
These plates are marked on the base with the reign marks of the Wanli emperor.

Wucai porcelain could be decorated with fewer than five colours.
Wucai porcelain could be decorated with more than five colours.
Ming dynasty enamelling techniques allowed for some variety in tone.
Gradations in colour and shading were limited.
Innovations in the Kangxi period included the addition of opaque white derived from lead arsenate.
Innovations in the Kangxi period included the addition of transparent ruby enamel derived from colloidal gold.
These innovations led to the development of new variations of wucai, such as famille rose.
Famille rose was highly prized in Europe.

u9oj1jy9.text: Pair of ko-akae plates
The plates are painted in a wucai palette of red, green, brown, and yellow overglaze enamels.
The scenes on these plates show a Buddhist monk seated on the ground surrounded by tea utensils.
The figure may be Kanaka Bharadvaja, a luohan ('perfected being', rakan in Japanese).
In Buddhist art, a luohan is commonly depicted with a book and a fly whisk.
Ko-akae means 'old red wares' in Japan.
Ko-akae are the colourful equivalents of ko-sometsuke dishes made in China in the seventeenth century.
Ko-akae dishes were made for use in meals accompanying the Japanese tea ceremony.
The plates feature characteristic surface flaws that tea practitioners found appealing.
The surface flaws include glaze bubbles and worn edges.
The protective brown enamel on the rims and greater regularity and delicacy of shape when compared to many ko-sometsuke reflect the complex aesthetic of the tea ceremony.
The aesthetic of the tea ceremony was defined as much by individual practitioners as by the sensibility of austerity, spontaneity, and apparent artlessness.
The sensibility of austerity, spontaneity, and apparent artlessness was promoted by influential masters like Sen no Rikyu (1522-1591).
Such wares were marked on the base with the marks of the Daoguang emperor.
Such wares were produced during a relatively brief period between the reigns of the Tianqi and Kangxi emperors.

These reign marks were probably added later as a mark of respect.
Other names for ko-akae include Tenkei akae, based on their prolific production during the reign of the Tianqi emperor, called Tenkei in Japanese.
Other names for ko-akae include Nankin akae, due to the Japanese belief that they were decorated in Nanjing.
Ceramics were rarely exported to Europe.
Europe preferred more highly finished and thinly bodied polychrome ceramics.
In Chinese art, luohans are often represented both collectively or as individuals.
In Japanese art, luohans are more commonly represented singly.

A brilliant translucent green enamel was added to the existing wucai palette of yellow, red, green, aubergine, and underglaze blue.

Porcelain with predominantly green and yellow designs came to be known as famille verte in the West in the late nineteenth century.

Robert Hobson attested to the popularity of these colours in his early catalogues of Chinese ceramics in the British Museum.

George Salting, Ernest Grandidier, and Anthony de Rothschild were major antiquarians of this era.

The exterior is decorated with four cartouches.
Two plates contain freely painted flowers.

u9plutcg.text: Worcester, England, 1770s Soft-paste porcelain, diameter 22.2 cm Asian Civilisations Museum, 2007-55811 Gift of Mr and Mrs Toshio Egawa
The pattern with a phoenix and a qilin, surrounded by kraak-style panels of flora and fauna, is based on an early eighteenth-century Chinese design.
The creature takes on an even more fantastical appearance in the hands of the Worcester enamellers.
The Chinese famille verte originals from the Kangxi reign feature brighter colours.
This design first appeared on Worcester porcelain around 1770.
This design was only used to decorate dessert services.
The design is called the Bishop Sumner pattern.
The pattern is possibly named after one of two bishops named Sumner from the late eighteenth and nineteenth century.
One of the bishops named Sumner may have owned a Worcester service with this pattern.
The Worcester porcelain factory distinguished itself from other manufactories in England through the use of large proportions of soaprock in its ceramics.
The use of soaprock in Worcester ceramics made them tougher than most other types of English porcelain.
Worcester ceramics were better able to withstand sudden changes in temperature due to the use of soaprock.

r0dbfp6i.text: Worcester, England, 1770s Soft-paste porcelain, diameter 11.8 and 14.7 cm Asian Civilisations Museum, 2007-55773, 2007-55802 Gift of Mr and Mrs Toshio Egawa
The design on these bowls features mythical beasts alternating with tables bearing vases of flowers.
The design on these bowls derives from a Kangxi famille verte pattern dating from the early eighteenth century.
One of the most popular Chinese-inspired porcelain patterns produced in England was mainly used to decorate tea wares.
One of the most popular Chinese-inspired porcelain patterns produced in England was mainly used to decorate dessert wares.
Worcester was the first factory to produce wares with this pattern.
Worcester began producing wares with this pattern around 1768.
Many other English factories made it in the late eighteenth century.
Many other English factories made it in the early nineteenth century.
The name of the pattern ‘Dragon in Compartments’ originated in the 1780s at the Chamberlain factory.
The pattern ‘Dragon in Compartments’ was also simply called ‘pattern number 75’ at the Chamberlain factory.
Collectors and dealers sometimes refer to the pattern as 'Bengal Tiger'.
Collectors and dealers sometimes refer to the pattern as 'Kylin', a variant spelling of qilin.

qwvs0vws.text: Probably Copperas Hill, Liverpool, England, ca.
1780 Soft-paste porcelain, height 9.1 cm Asian Civilisations Museum, 2007-55782
Chinese figures frequently appear on porcelain made in English factories in the 1700s.
Some wares are close copies of Chinese originals.
Some wares may have been produced to replace broken or missing pieces in valuable sets imported from China.
Other objects feature freely adapted patterns.
The figures on this sparrow-beak milk jug are from a coffee service.
Boys are painted on both objects.
A lady holding a fan is painted on both objects.
The simple figures are rendered almost as caricatures.
Facial features and hair are delineated with just a few brushstrokes.
This manner of drawing is characteristic of the enamelled wares produced by John Pennington at the Copperas Hill works.
The Copperas Hill works was an important porcelain factory in Liverpool.

w5gphrvu.text: The speckled blue surface of these objects, called ‘powder blue’, was created by blowing cobalt blue through a bamboo tube onto unfired porcelain.
The technique of creating ‘powder blue’ surfaces was perfected in the Kangxi period.
Specially shaped resists were used to create blank areas on wares like this.
The blank areas were subsequently painted in overglaze enamels.
The wares were then fired a second time.
A third firing fixed gilded designs onto the surface of the blue ground.
The three-stage decoration and firing of such objects were complex.
The complex decoration and firing made such objects luxurious.
The decoration and firing made such objects expensive export items.
The decorations often included figures and objects that European consumers found appealing.
A slender Chinese lady is depicted in several panels on the vase.
In the Dutch language, she was called Lange Lijs.
Lange Lijs became 'Long Eliza' in English.
One of the most popular designs on export wares from the Kangxi period was widely imitated in European porcelain.
The design was particularly imitated on plates and bowls from Worcester in the 1760s.

Jingdezhen, China (Qing dynasty) Kangxi period, 1662–1722   
Porcelain with powder blue glaze, gilding and overglaze enamels,   
height 43.3 cm, diameter 27 cm   
HKU.C.1954.0136, HKU.C.1976.0623

e2mguhlf.text: Powder blue porcelains with gilded decoration were exported to Europe.
The inscriptions, shape, and painted scenes on this brush pot suggest that it was made for a Chinese audience.
The Chinese audience was interested in and familiar with the scholars named and the literati community they represented.

kwqakp7q.text: Rouleau vase
China (Qing dynasty), Kangxi period, 1662–1722 Porcelain with powder blue glaze and gilding, height 15 cm HKU.C.1953.0050
This brush pot is decorated with an image in gold on powder blue glaze.
This brush pot is decorated with an inscription in gold on powder blue glaze.
The text displays the poem A Visit to the Red Cliffs at Night by the Ming dynasty official Luo Hongxian.
Luo Hongxian lived from 1504 to 1564.
Luo was a cartographer and scholar.
Luo’s interest in topography and the Chinese landscape is well expressed in his poem.
Luo’s poem was written in response to the Ode to the Red Cliffs by the Northern Song scholar Su Shi.
Su Shi was a Northern Song scholar who lived from 1037 to 1101.
Luo wrote that he visited the Red Cliffs five hundred years after Su Shi.
Luo wrote that the scenery was as beautiful as it was in the past.
He described his attempts to retrace Su Shi’s footsteps.
He described the sight of fishermen who came to sell fish in a silent landscape.
He described lonely cranes flying above a river.
Painted scenes accompany the poem.
The painted scenes show the river and scholars in a boat.
China (Qing dynasty), Kangxi period, 1662–1722 Porcelain with powder blue glaze and gilding, height 44 cm HKU.C.1953.0012
This vase is inscribed with an essay accompanied by a landscape showing a fisherman and a farmer outside the walls of a pavilion.
The finely executed golden characters copy the famous preface to the Pavilion of Prince Teng ('Tengwang Ge Xu').
The preface to the Pavilion of Prince Teng was written by the Tang dynasty scholar Wang Bo (650–676).
The text is an important example of Tang literature.
The text was written as Wang Bo traveled to see his father in Jiaozhi County, which is in present-day northern Vietnam.
Wang Bo encountered a grand banquet en route to Jiaozhi County.
During the banquet, he completed his text.
He laments his inability to benefit from his talent.
He drowned in the South China Sea at age 26.
He drowned before reaching his father.

w8xsgvch.text: Pair of mounted jars
Jingdezhen, China, Qianlong period, 1736–1795; mounts added in France, 18th or 19th century Porcelain with gilt-bronze mounts, 45 x 28 cm Asian Civilisations Museum, 2014-00709
This pair of jars combines some of the best features of the decorative arts of eighteenth-century China.
This pair of jars combines some of the best features of the decorative arts of eighteenth-century Europe.
The powder blue porcelain vessels have an elegant profile.
The porcelain vessels have an undulating profile.
The gilded bronze mounts show dragons.
The bronze mounts were finely sculpted, cast, and gilded in France.
The bronze mounts were likely created during the reign of Louis XV (1710–1774).
Imported wares were often mounted with extravagant gilt-bronze settings.
The gilt-bronze settings adopted the stylistic vocabulary and fantastic forms of French rococo.
The gilt-bronze settings made unfamiliar Chinese forms more usable in European interiors.
Merchants called marchands-merciers specialised in marketing luxury objects.
Marchands-merciers facilitated the addition of mounts to porcelain.
Marchands-merciers drew on extensive networks of silversmiths, craftsmen and decorators.
This pair of vessels demonstrates the high regard for fine Chinese porcelain at the European courts.
The earliest recorded Chinese blue-and-white ceramic object in France reached the court of Henry II via Constantinople.
The ceramic object was a gift from Suleiman the Magnificent, Sultan of the Ottoman Empire.
Further gifts were presented by the Siamese ambassador Phra Narai to Louis XIV in 1686.
Objects imported by the French East India Company helped spread a fashion for such exotica.
The intense blue of these Chinese jars may well have been an inspiration for the Sevres blue.
The Sevres blue made the French royal manufactory famous later in the eighteenth century.

ya05rgjh.text: Pair of custard cups
Jingdezhen, China (Qing dynasty), Qianlong period, ca.

1790s   
Porcelain with underglaze and overglaze enamels and gilding,   
height 9 and 8.7 cm   
Donated in memory of Miss Beryl Robina Wright   
HKU.C.1997.1288a-b
Lavishly painted and gilded porcelain services of the late eighteenth and early nineteenth century are sometimes called 'palace ware'.
These porcelain services are usually decorated with outdoor scenes of noble men and women.
The name was first used by collectors in New York, Boston, and Philadelphia in the 1930s.
The name was used to refer to the ostentatious detail and subject matter.
Late export porcelain of this type was typically made, glazed, and fired at Jingdezhen.
Late export porcelain of this type was decorated in Canton.
Late export porcelain of this type was shipped from Canton to Europe and America.
These custard cups are part of a larger dinner service of dishes, plates, saucers, platters, tureens, bowls, and cups suitable for a grand interior.
Each object is decorated with a central scene in the famille rose palette showing men and women among pavilions and mountainous landscapes.
The scenes are surrounded by several painted and gilded borders with geometric and floral patterns.
The borders are interrupted by small panels showing birds, flowers, and landscapes in iron-red or sepia.
This design has been referred to as the ‘Rockefeller pattern’ since 1979.
The ‘Rockefeller pattern’ is associated with the famous Rockefeller family of New York.
John D. Rockefeller, Jr (1874–1960) was the son and heir of the dynasty's founder.
John D. Rockefeller, Jr owned a dessert service with the pattern.
The service was owned by Charles Stirling prior to being acquired by the Rockefellers.
The service was probably commissioned by Charles Stirling.
Charles Stirling was a wealthy Scottish landowner involved in the China trade.
Another service of the same design is known to have been ordered by John Roberts, a Director of the British East India Company.
The service was likely ordered around 1805.
The dissemination of these services through inheritance accounts for the presence of many individual pieces in different collections today.
The dissemination of these services through sale accounts for the presence of many individual pieces in different collections today.
The famille rose palette used to paint the central scenes was developed in China during the late Kangxi period.
Jesuit priests worked with craftsmen at the Yangxindian ('Hall of Mental Cultivation') within the Forbidden City to develop the famille rose palette.
It is characterised by soft pinks and reds created by mixing ruby red derived from colloidal gold and opaque white enamel.
The mixture of ruby red and opaque white enamel allowed for a great range of tones and shading.
The development of this enamel in China was roughly contemporaneous with rose du barry enamels invented in France in the eighteenth century.
Rose du barry enamels were named after the Comtesse du Barry, mistress to Louis XV.
The Comtesse du Barry was a patron of the Sèvres porcelain factory.

xmttco9e.text: Bowl with doucai enamels
Doucai porcelains are decorated with a combination of underglaze blue and overglaze enamels.
Like wucai, doucai means 'fitted-colour'.
On wucai porcelain, underglaze dark blue is applied in bold washes to complement strong overglaze colours, usually within outlines in red, brown, or black.
Doucai porcelain features pale enamel washes with outlines in soft underglaze blue.
The technique was developed during the reign of the Xuande emperor.
The technique was perfected in the Chenghua period.
The decoration has been used to depict mandarin ducks in a lotus pond on this bowl.
The rim of the bowl is framed by a band of stylised, possibly Sanskrit, characters.
Mandarin ducks were mistakenly thought to mate for life.
Pairs of mandarin ducks are an auspicious symbol for a happy marriage in China.
Lotuses are homophonous in Chinese with the word for harmony (he).
Lotuses may be interpreted as expressing the wish for many sons.
Ceramics pairing the motifs of lotuses and harmony originate in the decorative arts of the Tang dynasty.
Similar designs were used on Yuan dynasty blue-and-white dishes.
Similar designs were used on enamelled ceramics from the Ming dynasty.
Similar designs were used on kraak wares made for export to Europe.
The designs appear to have been a popular adornment for Ming jardinières.
Ming jardinières were used as aquaria.
Ming jardinières were used to grow water plants.

bje83sbq.text: The earliest enamelled porcelains with ducks and lotus flowers alternating in a row on the exterior appear to date to the Jiajing period.
An iron-red, green, and yellow bowl from the British Museum is illustrated in Harrison-Hall 2001.
This plate depicts a red five-clawed dragon writhing in mid-air.
The red five-clawed dragon is above blue swirling waves.
The colour combination was achieved by painting waves in cobalt oxide under a clear glaze.
The clay was fired at a high temperature.
Red enamels were fused on in a subsequent low-temperature firing.
Dragons against breaking waves were popular designs from the Ming dynasty onward.
Underglaze-blue and red examples can be found with reign marks of nearly all the Qing emperors.
Jingdezhen, China (Qing dynasty), Daoguang period, 1821–1850 Porcelain with underglaze blue and overglaze enamels, diameter 13.8 cm HKU.C.2009.1809
China (Qing dynasty), Daoguang period, 1821–1850 Porcelain with blue underglaze and overglaze enamels, diameter 17.5 cm HKU.C.1978.0637

q0bg1n7y.text: Commemorative plate
Spode, England, ca.
1822 Stone china with overglaze enamels, diameter 25.7 cm Hong Kong Maritime Museum, HKMM2013.0040.0001
This plate was made in Spode, England.
This plate carries the arms of the Honourable East India Company.
The motto of the Honourable East India Company on this plate is 'Auspicio Regis et Senatus Angliae' ('By right of the King and the Senate of England').
The first English East India Company was established in 1600.
The first English East India Company was named ‘The Governor and Company of Merchants of London trading into the East Indies’.
The organization was formed to pursue trade with maritime Southeast Asia.
The organization eventually came to dominate half of the world’s trade.
In 1698, its name was changed to the Honourable East India Company.
In 1709, a new coat of arms, shown on this plate, was adopted.
Armorial porcelains were a major component of the global trade in porcelain for centuries.
Blue-and-white dishes made in Jingdezhen for export to Portugal in the 1540s marked the beginning of this trade.
Britain was a major consumer of armorial porcelain from China.
Britain accounted for over half of the total amount of armorial porcelain produced before America entered the China trade in 1784.
By the eighteenth century, British porcelain manufactories were producing such wares.
This plate may have been part of a larger service ordered from the Spode factory by the East India Company in 1822 or 1823.
The service may have been intended for use in the East India Company’s factory in Canton.
A banner on the reverse reads 'The London'.
The banner references the ship which brought the ceramics to China in 1824.
John Barnet Sotherby, the captain, may have ordered several plates for his own use.
The Spode factory developed 'stone china' in 1813.
Stone china is a variety of tough earthenware.
It was one of many similar earthenwares made as substitutes for porcelain after the East India Company responded to the success of the European porcelain industry.
The East India Company reduced large-scale imports of Chinese export porcelain in 1791 due to declining demand.

h6vrizti.text: The design on this irregularly-shaped plate shows a landscape with two scholars enjoying nature.
The design on this irregularly-shaped plate shows two scholars playing go.
A young man crosses a bridge with picnic supplies.
The young man is probably an attendant.
The plum trees and chrysanthemum blossoms in the foreground are painted in soft pink-reds.
Soft pink-reds are a hallmark of the famille rose palette.
The famille rose palette is called fencai ('powdered colours') in Chinese.
The plate is marked with the reign marks of the Xianfeng emperor.
The plate represents a rare example of porcelain produced during a period of intense political chaos.
Rebels from the Taiping Heavenly Kingdom seized much of southern China during Xianfeng's reign in the 1850s.
Rebels from the Taiping Heavenly Kingdom burned Jingdezhen to the ground in 1853.
The kilns were not rebuilt until the rebels were defeated in 1864.
By 1864, China was suffering increasing encroachment by European powers.
Jingdezhen, China (Qing dynasty), Xianfeng period, 1851–1861 Porcelain with overglaze enamels, 17 x 2.8 cm HKU.C.1981.0856

bqe1w559.text: Qingbai and celadon

Large kiln sites in northern and southern China were producing glazed porcelain and stoneware in various shades of blue, green, and white centuries before the flowering of blue-and-white wares in the fourteenth century.
The porcelain and stoneware produced were adorned with elegant incised decoration.
Qingbai, also known as 'green-white,' is a translucent porcelain with a bluish-green glaze produced at kiln complexes in Jingdezhen and Jizhou.
Celadon is a type of porcelain or stoneware with an olive-green glaze.
Celadon takes its name from a character with a distinctive outfit in L’Astrée, a seventeenth-century French comedy.
These ceramics were similar in color to valuable jade.
These ceramics were among the most highly regarded in China.
Celadon from the Longquan kilns in Lishui, Zhejiang province was particularly highly regarded.
The Longquan kilns supplied the Southern Song court after the collapse of the northern dynasty in 1127.
Some scholars prefer the term 'greenware' for these ceramics to avoid using arbitrary Western nomenclature.
Chinese qingbai and celadon wares were exported to East Asia.
Chinese qingbai and celadon wares were exported to Southeast Asia.
Chinese qingbai and celadon wares were exported to the Islamic world.
Celadon wares in the Islamic world were thought to break or change colour if touched by poison.
Artifacts were most eagerly collected in regions situated firmly within China’s sphere of cultural and political influence.
Japan was a region situated firmly within China’s sphere of cultural and political influence.
Song dynasty celadon was shipped from Ningbo in Zhejiang province to Japan.
During the Kamakura period, celadon became the favored form of utensils and interior decoration for the Japanese tea ceremony.
Celadon formed part of a fashion for karamono, meaning 'Chinese things'.
The popularity of celadon is attested to by thousands of shards recovered from historic sites.
Many intact examples of celadon are preserved in major Japanese temples.
Refined Chinese celadon pieces were brought to the imperial court by official embassies in Korea during the Goryeo period (918–1392).
Refined Chinese celadon pieces were seen as the pinnacle of ceramic artistry in Korea during the Goryeo period (918–1392).
Local potters were soon making their own versions of pottery.
Local potters combined stylistic elements drawn directly from Chinese wares.
Local potters created new designs articulated for Korean consumers.
And in Mainland Southeast Asia, green-glazed ceramics reminiscent of celadon were among the first stonewares to be produced,
using kiln technologies from China that allowed ceramics to be fired at much higher temperatures.
Ceramics were made at a number of sites in Vietnam along the Red River Delta during the thirteenth and fourteenth centuries.
Ceramics were most famously made at Sawankhalok in the fifteenth century.
Ceramics formed one of the early Thai kingdom's most important export commodities during the fifteenth century.
The absence was most likely the result of changing fashions in Asia.
By the sixteenth century, Europe began direct trade with China.
Celadon wares had largely been supplanted in the domestic market by blue-and-white porcelain.
Established kilns that had focused on celadon before the fourteenth century turned their attention to the production of blue-and-white wares.
Some kilns, such as those in Longquan, Cizhou, and Jizhou, continued to produce celadon and other monochromatic ceramics in smaller quantities.
Song examples of celadon and monochromatic ceramics remained popular among collectors in later periods.
Qingbai is also referred to as yingqing (‘shadow green’).
The name yingqing (‘shadow green’) appears only to date from the eighteenth century.
Some theories suggest that the name celadon is a corruption of 'Saladin', the Ayyubid Sultan.
Saladin sent forty pieces of the ceramic to the Sultan of Syria in 1171.
Other theories suggest that the name celadon derives from the Sanskrit words sila and dhara.
The Sanskrit words sila and dhara mean 'green' and 'stone'.

xmzy68s9.text: Celadon was never sent to Europe in significant numbers.
Celadon was never made with Western consumers in mind.
The rare examples that did arrive were diplomatic gifts from rulers in the Islamic world.
The diplomatic gifts were sometimes given elaborate metalwork mounts.
Only three surviving Chinese ceramic pieces can be documented as reaching Europe before 1500.
The Fonthill Vase, which is qingbai, is now in Dublin.
A Longquan celadon dish was presented to Lorenzo de’ Medici by the Mamluk Sultan of Egypt in 1487.
The ‘Katzenelnbogen bowl’ was bought by an aristocratic German pilgrim in the Holy Land in 1433–1434.
The ‘Katzenelnbogen bowl’ was given a cover and mounts in gilded silver upon the pilgrim's return.
China (Southern Song dynasty), 1127–1279 Porcelain with white-green glaze, diameter 22 cm HKU.C.1994.1000

o8vr9ndw.text: Qingbai wares were first produced in the early Northern Song dynasty at kilns in Jingdezhen.
Kilns in Jingdezhen were successfully manufacturing celadon wares for the local market at the time.
The icy blue-green tinge was produced by applying a glaze with small amounts of iron to a fine porcelain stone and kaolin clay body.
The porcelain stone and kaolin clay body was fired in an oxygen-deprived atmosphere.
The colour of the glazes ranged from a very thin and pale white to a pale blue-green.
The pale blue-green colour is often associated with celadon.
A related form of qingbai with iron oxide seemingly randomly spotted and splashed over vessels was one of the earliest experiments in underglaze decoration.
The scrolling floral patterns on these bowls were common decorative forms used on contemporary metalwork in the Song dynasty.
The scrolling floral patterns on these bowls were common decorative forms used on lacquer in the Song dynasty.

fb2osf2j.text: Bowl
Qingbai bowls and dishes were often fired upside down in the kiln.
A technique used to manufacture Ding wares in northern China was adopted for qingbai bowls and dishes.
This saved space in the kiln by allowing for everted vessels to be stacked in a pile.
This was essential for mass-produced utilitarian wares.
This was essential for export wares.
It helped to evenly spread the weight of each vessel around the rim.
It prevented deformation.
It allowed for more thinly potted bodies.
Vessels fired in this way had to be wiped free of glaze on the rim to prevent them from becoming attached to the kiln floor.
Wiping the glaze on the rim resulted in a rough, unfinished appearance.
Potters sometimes covered the unglazed area with copper rims to avoid damage.
Potters sometimes covered the unglazed area with silver rims to avoid damage.
Copper rims were used on this bowl to cover the unglazed area.
Silver rims were used on this bowl to cover the unglazed area.
China (Southern Song dynasty), 1127–1279 Porcelain with white-green glaze, diameter 22 cm HKU.C.1989.0958
Qingbai wares were produced in a variety of forms for the domestic market.
Qingbai wares included utilitarian bowls, dishes and teapots for daily use.
Qingbai wares included more elaborate figures and jars for burial.
Qingbai ceramics were not generally made for the imperial court.
Qingbai ceramics were appreciated by Song connoisseurs.
The ceramic historian Jiang Qi likened qingbai ceramics to jade in his work 'Tao ji' ('Records on Ceramics').
'Tao ji' ('Records on Ceramics') was written between 1214 and 1234.
Valuable export items were popular with various trading communities in Java.
The popularity of valuable export items in Java is mentioned in Zhao Rugua's Zhufanzhi.
Zhufanzhi is a thirteenth-century document which describes foreign customs and commodities traded in South East Asia and the Indian Ocean during the Song dynasty.
China (Southern Song dynasty), 1127–1279 Porcelain with white-green glaze, copper, diameter 20.5 cm HKU.C.2009.1810

ndvnktxc.text: This qingbai jar is modeled after woven rattan or willow containers called liudou ('willow jars').
Liudou ('willow jars') were used in agriculture to measure grains.
Imitations of these jars were produced from the Tang period onwards.
Imitations of these jars were initially produced in metal.
Imitations of these jars were later produced in earthenware and stoneware.
Few qingbai jars in these shapes are known.
Ceramic liudou with other glazes were sometimes produced at kilns in Yaozhou and Ganzhou.
A notable example of ceramic liudou was recovered from the Sinan wreck.
The Sinan wreck was a Chinese cargo vessel that sank off the Sinan coast of Korea in 1323.
The Sinan wreck was on a voyage to ports in Korea, Japan, and presumably Southeast Asia.
Educated men in the Song dynasty demonstrated their cultural refinement by collecting objects from the past.
Educated men in the Song dynasty published catalogues illustrating historical jades and bronzes.
Contemporary Song craftsmen responded to this behavior by reproducing antiquarian forms in other materials.
Contemporary Song craftsmen often reproduced antiquarian forms as commissions for wealthy clients.
New users adapted the functions of these objects to suit their needs.
This jar was most likely used for burning incense.
This jar was most likely used for offering food to deceased ancestors.
This jar was most likely not used as an agricultural tool.

kaia8js2.text: The jar features the thick, translucent, and richly textured celadon glaze characteristic of ceramics made in the Longquan kilns.
Longquan celadon was highly valued in East Asia, particularly in Japan.
The glaze of Longquan celadon came to be known as kinuta in Japan.
Kinuta refers to a mallet, after mallet-shaped vases from Longquan that were imported into Japan in the Southern Song and Yuan dynasties.
Burial jars were among the earliest types of ceramics produced in the Longquan kilns.
A pair of these jars in the Percival David Foundation is illustrated in Medley 1977, pl.
China (Southern Song dynasty), 1127–1279 Porcelain with white-green glaze, 7.1 x 10 cm HKU.C.1994.1001
Longquan, China (Southern Song dynasty), 1127–1279 Stoneware with celadon glaze, height 23 cm HKU.C.1996.1076
Several vessels have been excavated from tombs in southern China.
The vessels are thought to have been employed to store grains used in burial ceremonies.
One bore around its shoulder the ‘Green Dragon of the East’.
The other bore the ‘White Tiger of the West’.
The ‘Green Dragon of the East’ and the ‘White Tiger of the West’ are creatures of Daoist mythology.
Creatures of Daoist mythology were used to decorate coffins and tombs from as early as the Han dynasty (206 BCE–CE 220).
They may have been filled with aromatic oils and then placed on their respective sides of the deceased, whose head would have been placed pointing north.

edfn3ekz.text: Longquan was once one of the largest manufacturing centres of celadon in China.
By the time of the Qing dynasty, the Longquan kilns had declined significantly.
More than three hundred individual kilns operated in Longquan during the Song and Yuan dynasties.
Fewer than a third of these kilns remained active in the seventeenth century.
The kilns that remained active continued to produce works of occasional brilliance.
This later type of celadon was primarily intended for antiquarian collectors or commissioned by the imperial court.
This later type of celadon evoked the taste and styles of earlier periods.
A revival of interest during the reigns of the Kangxi and Yongzheng emperors led to the development of several new techniques and forms.
The delicate, almost watery tone of celadon on this vase was a Kangxi innovation.
The delicate tone of celadon was produced by lessening the amount of iron typically found in Song dynasty Longquan celadon glazes.
Longquan, China (Qing dynasty), Kangxi period, 1662–1722 Stoneware with celadon glaze, height 23.7 cm HKU.C.1953.0015

d2hy37c6.text: Ceramics with green glazes were the only high-fired wares produced in Korea during the Goryeo dynasty.
Ceramics were first introduced from China around the tenth century.
By the middle of the twelfth century, Korean potters had developed their own distinctive traditions.
These traditions included shapes and designs that reflected native tastes.
Korean wares were extolled in contemporaneous Chinese writings as having the 'clarity of water'.
Korean wares were extolled in contemporaneous Chinese writings as having the 'radiance of jade'.
The interior of this bowl is finely incised with two long-tailed parrots.
The two long-tailed parrots are positioned as if chasing each other.
The patterns were carved with a knife, a technique known as eumgak cheongja ('incised celadon').
Eumgak cheongja ('incised celadon') flourished in Korea during the twelfth century.
The brown hue of the glaze is likely the result of poor control of oxygen levels during the firing process.
Three small spur marks on the base are the remnants of sand, pebbles, or shells commonly used to raise ceramic vessels off the kiln floor.
Raising ceramic vessels off the kiln floor prevents their bases from picking up residue or being deformed.

nj06q3xo.text: Bowl with cranes and clouds
The bowl is decorated with scrolling floral patterns and flying cranes among clouds.
The bowl is an example of a type of celadon with inlaid designs called sanggam cheongja.
This technique is unique to Korea.
The technique involves etching the desired motifs onto a dry clay body.
The carved space is filled in with a black or white slip.
A translucent glaze is applied after the carved space is filled.
The vessel is fired after the translucent glaze is applied.
It developed in the mid-twelfth century.
It was possibly inspired by contemporary metalworking techniques.
It was possibly inspired by contemporary lacquer techniques.
Much of the symbolism used in Korean art was adapted from the Chinese decorative repertoire.
The adaptation of symbolism occurred as a result of the close cultural ties between Korea and China.
Many designs used on celadon wares and other decorative objects are associated with Buddhism, Daoism, or Confucianism.
Buddhism, Daoism, and Confucianism were supported by the ruling class at various times.
Buddhism, Daoism, and Confucianism came to permeate social and religious life.
The cranes on this bowl would have carried similar associations with cranes in China.
Cranes in China symbolise longevity.
The swirling cloud patterns in the background were a common decorative backdrop used to supplement central motifs.
The swirling cloud patterns in the background are almost identical to patterns found on Goryeo embroidery.

Cups like this might have been used for drinking tea.
Cups like this might have been used for eating rice.
Celadon cups were key vessels used in literati gatherings.
Celadon cups were used for wine drinking during festive occasions.
Various kinds of celadon wares, such as bowls and dishes, were used at royal banquets.
Various kinds of celadon wares, such as bowls and dishes, were sometimes exchanged as diplomatic gifts.

Sawankhalok, Thailand, 15th or 16th century Stoneware with celadon glaze, diameter 28.6 cm Asian Civilisations Museum, 1998-00966
The Thai kingdom of Sukhothai was founded in the early thirteenth century.
The Thai kingdom of Sukhothai was one of the most important ceramic production centres in Southeast Asia.
There were two main centres of production: one in the capital, Sukhothai.
There was a larger complex in Sawankhalok, also called Si Satchanalai, to the north.
The earliest celadons from these sites were probably made around 1400.
Many examples of celadons were recovered from the Nanyang and Longquan wrecks.
The Nanyang and Longquan wrecks sunk in the South China Sea around 1380 and 1400 respectively.
These wares appear to have been influenced by green-glazed ceramics introduced to China in the fourteenth century via maritime trade.
Thai envoys sent to China brought celadon wares back with them after providing tribute to the Ming court.
Thai tradition attributes the development of celadon to Chinese refugees who arrived in Thailand after the collapse of the Song dynasty in 1279.
Celadon wares from Sawankhalok demonstrate a range of Chinese, Khmer, and Vietnamese influences.
Celadon wares from Sawankhalok are distinctly Thai in their choice of motifs and shapes.
Celadon wares from Sawankhalok have a characteristic soft green tone achieved by applying green glaze over a white slip.
Thai kilns took advantage of disruptions to production in China to send their ceramics to the Indonesian Archipelago, Malay Peninsula, and other parts of Southeast Asia.
These ceramics became popular export items in the fifteenth century.
Sawankhalok celadon comprises a major part of the cargo of the mid-fifteenth century Royal Nanhai.
The Royal Nanhai is the wreck of a Siamese junk heading for Java.
The Royal Nanhai was carrying over 20,000 ceramic items.
Southeast Asian celadon appears to have been the dominant form until around 1488.
Southeast Asian celadon was supplanted by Burmese examples around 1488.

Miniature objects such as figurines, jarlets, cups and bottles were used in local Thai ritual practices.
Miniature objects were sometimes used in association with small portable shrines.
These examples were often decorated with pale olive-green crackled glaze.
The lower sections of these examples were left unglazed to show their brownish-red bodies.
Miniatures were the most common type of celadon wares manufactured at the Sawankhalok kilns.
Miniatures were produced both for domestic consumption and for export.

zo1rc9gp.text: Northern Vietnam, 14th century Stoneware, height 12.8 cm Asian Civilisations Museum, 2000-01239
This jar includes moulded decorations of floral scrolls applied to the outer wall.
The base is incised with three characters: tian, chang, and kou.
The characters tian, chang, and kou literally mean 'heaven', 'long', and 'mouth'.
The celadon is typical of the high-quality celadon produced in northern Vietnam during the Tran dynasty (1225–1400).
Vietnamese kilns along the banks of the Red River began exporting ceramics to Turkey, Egypt, Indonesia, and Japan during the so-called Ming gap.
Vietnamese potters exported ceramics to fill the vacuum left by the trade with China from the fourteenth to sixteenth centuries.
Potters in Thailand also exported ceramics during the so-called Ming gap.
The output of these kilns reflected contemporary stylistic changes in the Middle Kingdom.
The popularity of ivory- and celadon-glazed vessels soon yielded to ceramics with painted decoration in iron brown or cobalt blue.
